distributional 0.3.0.9000

The Pareto distribution

Source: R/dist_pareto.R
dist_pareto.Rd

dist_pareto(shape, scale)

Arguments

shape, scale

parameters. Must be strictly positive.

See also

actuar::Pareto

Examples

dist <- dist_pareto(shape = c(10, 3, 2, 1), scale = rep(1, 4))
dist
#> <distribution[4]>
#> [1] Pareto(10, 1) Pareto(3, 1)  Pareto(2, 1)  Pareto(1, 1) 

mean(dist)
#> [1] 0.1111111 0.5000000 1.0000000       Inf
variance(dist)
#> [1] 0.0154321 0.7500000       Inf       NaN
support(dist)
#> <support_region[4]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1] 0.157150147 0.243821589 0.005410674 0.002386787 0.143299093 0.198550631
#>  [7] 0.030007901 0.029927182 0.051261083 0.074119647
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1] 0.44546242 0.06676408 0.02003467 0.12168998 0.05972229 0.06923544
#>  [7] 0.02225472 0.16070583 2.92757388 1.30445415
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1] 1.73243476 0.92251349 0.28430270 1.41529396 0.15382757 0.59423618
#>  [7] 0.52738231 0.02748329 1.90937495 1.10929746
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.31473710 0.24432575 0.51121583 0.03992337 1.70458348 0.27640810
#>  [7] 1.26741144 2.57433659 0.03498035 2.51916683
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 5.645029e-05 3.703704e-02 7.407407e-02 1.111111e-01
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -9.782150 -3.295837 -2.602690 -2.197225

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.9999999 0.9920000 0.9600000 0.8000000

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 0.1279449 0.4938016 0.8257419 2.3333333
